Text: Praise the LORD. Praise the name of the LORD; praise Him, O servants of the LORD,
Context: The psalm opens with a call for the servants of the LORD to praise His name, setting a tone of worship and reverence.

Text: you who stand in the house of the LORD, in the courts of the house of our God.
Context: The verse implies spatial settings in which the praising takes place. It emphasizes service and presence in the sacred spaces of the LORD’s house.

Text: Praise the LORD, for the LORD is good; sing praises to His name, for it is pleasant.
Context: The verse reinforces the goodness of the LORD and the pleasing nature of worship, suggesting a harmonious and joyful relationship with God.

Text: For the LORD has chosen Jacob for Himself, Israel as His treasured possession.
Context: The verse speaks of God‘s special choice of Israel, connoting a sense of favor and exclusivity in the relationship between God and His people.

Text: For I know that the LORD is great; our Lord is above all gods.
Context: The psalmist expresses a confident acknowledgment of the LORD’s greatness and supremacy above all other deities.

Text: Whatever the LORD pleases, He does in the heavens and on earth, in the seas and all their depths.
Context: The verse depicts God‘s omnipotence and his unrestricted ability to act according to His will in all realms of existence.

Text: He causes the clouds to rise from the ends of the earth. He sends lightning with the rain and brings the wind out of His storehouses.
Context: This verse describes natural phenomena as under the direct command of God, suggesting His control over creation.

Text: He struck down the firstborn of Egypt, both man and beast.
Context: Here, the verse recalls God’s acts of judgment and power as seen in the deliverance of Israel from Egypt.

Text: He sent signs and wonders into your midst, O Egypt, against Pharaoh and all his servants.
Context: The verse further elaborates on God‘s demonstrated power through signs and wonders in Egypt, underscoring His ability to overcome human authorities.

Text: He struck down many nations and slaughtered mighty kings—
Context: This verse continues the theme of God’s justice, bringing defeat to nations and mighty rulers opposing His will.

Text: Sihon king of the Amorites, Og king of Bashan, and all the kingdoms of Canaan.
Context: It specifies the particular historical victories orchestrated by God for Israel, evidencing His supportive action for His chosen people.

Text: He gave their land as an inheritance, an inheritance to His people Israel.
Context: This verse describes the tangible outcome of God‘s favor, the acquisition of land, a divine grant to His chosen people.

Text: Your name, O LORD, endures forever, your renown, O LORD, through all generations.
Context: The psalmist reflects on the eternal nature of the LORD’s name and fame, extending beyond temporary circumstances.

Text: For the LORD will vindicate His people and have compassion on His servants.
Context: This verse reassures of God‘s commitment to justice and mercy for His people, indicating ongoing care and concern.

Text: The idols of the nations are silver and gold, made by the hands of men.
Context: Transitioning to a contrasting theme, this verse begins to describe the nature of idols in contrast to the living God.

Text: They have mouths, but cannot speak; eyes, but cannot see;
Context: The verse points out the impotence of idols, having physical features but lacking any real power or life.

Text: They have ears, but cannot hear, nor is there breath in their mouths.
Context: Continuing from the previous verse, the psalmist emphasizes the lifelessness of idols, further highlighting their inherent powerlessness.

Text: Those who make them will be like them, and so will all who trust in them.
Context: There is a warning here that those who trust in idols will become as ineffectual and empty as the idols themselves.

Text: O house of Israel, bless the LORD; O house of Aaron, bless the LORD;
Context: The psalm shifts back to a call for blessings upon the LORD from the house of Israel and the priesthood.

Text: O house of Levi, bless the LORD; you who fear the LORD, bless the LORD.
Context: Further extending the call to various groups within the community of faith, urging a collective expression of blessing to God.

Text: Blessed be the LORD from Zion, who dwells in Jerusalem. Praise the LORD!
Context: This closing verse celebrates God’s presence in Jerusalem and ends with a jubilant ”Praise the LORD,“ echoing the opening of the psalm.
